content: Federal job training and employment programs aim to connect vulnerable youth to work and school. These young people are typically low-income with barriers to employment. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training and related services for unemployed and underemployed individuals, including youth. Programs under WIA, such as Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild, are carried out by the Department of Labor. The Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program is also implemented under WIA. These programs collectively form the federal job training system for youth. Title I of WIA includes programs like Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild, aimed at connecting youth to education, employment, leadership, and community service. WIA programs were authorized until September 30, 2003, but continue to be funded annually. Policy makers in the 112th Congress hinted at reauthorizing the law. This report discusses issues related to WIA youth programs, focusing on Youth Activities and Job Corps, as well as provisions in bills like H.R. 803 and S. 1356. It mentions programs like YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants. The curr_chunk discusses various youth programs authorized under WIA, including Youth Activities, Job Corps, YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants. These programs aim to provide job training and other services to low-income youth, with funding continuing for most programs except for Youth Opportunity Grants since FY2003. The Youth Activities, Job Corps, YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants programs aim to connect low-income youth to educational and employment opportunities. Each program serves youth with specific employment barriers, but they differ in their focus and services provided. YouthBuild requires participants to be high school dropouts and focuses on construction work, while the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program targets youth offenders and those at risk of dropping out. Job Corps is the only program offering residential services for youth. Workforce investment boards must provide 10 specific elements to youth in the program, including mentoring and follow-up. The Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program offers various activities for youth returning from secure facilities. Funding for these programs is allocated differently, with DOL distributing funds to local WIBs for Youth Activities and entering agreements with organizations to operate Job Corps centers. YouthBuild and the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program award grants to organizations. Additionally, DOL partners with nonprofit and for-profit organizations for Job Corps programs and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Forest Service for Job Corps programs on USDA lands. YouthBuild and the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program competitively award grants to organizations and local communities.
